support_summary: ATXN3 directly interacts with, deubiquitinates, and stabilizes HIF-2α (EPAS1), but not HIF-1α, to promote tumoral PD-L1 transcription under hypoxic conditions. The interaction was confirmed by co-immunoprecipitation in HEK293T and A549 cells.

functions.cellular_process: Under hypoxic conditions, the deubiquitinase ATXN3 directly interacts with the transcription factor EPAS1 (HIF-2α), but not the related HIF-1α. This interaction leads to the removal of ubiquitin chains from HIF-2α, protecting it from proteasomal degradation.
functions.effect_description: By preventing its ubiquitination-induced degradation, ATXN3 stabilizes the HIF-2α protein. This increases the intracellular levels of HIF-2α, enhancing its transcriptional activity and promoting the expression of hypoxia-response genes, such as the immune checkpoint protein PD-L1.
biological_consequence: Hypoxia induces ATXN3 expression -> ATXN3 directly binds to EPAS1 (HIF-2α) -> ATXN3 deubiquitinates EPAS1 -> EPAS1 is shielded from proteasomal degradation -> Stabilized EPAS1 accumulates -> EPAS1 transcribes target genes -> PD-L1 (CD274) transcription is increased -> Tumor immune evasion is promoted
specific_effects: Selectively interacts with and deubiquitinates HIF-2α, but not HIF-1α.
Increases the protein half-life and stability of HIF-2α.
Promotes the transcription of the immune checkpoint protein PD-L1 in tumor cells under hypoxic conditions.

evidence.paper_title: CRISPR screening identifies the deubiquitylase ATXN3 as a PD-L1–positive regulator for tumor immune evasion
evidence.relevant_quote: Collectively, our results indicate that ATXN3 enhances hypoxia-induced PD-L1 expression through protecting HIF-2α from ubiquitination-induced protein degradation.

summary: ATXN3 activates EPAS1 to modulate epas1 (hif-2α) protein stability.
